joe.util.bootstrap
Class BootstrapMain

java.lang.Object
  joe.util.bootstrap.BootstrapMain

public final class BootstrapMain
extends java.lang.Object

A general application entry point that loads and merges properties from different files, based on username and other properties. It can be invoked transparently: invocation without being explicitly enabled will have no effect other than to delegate through to the bootstrapped application with no changes to the environment.

Why would you want to do this?

This library is designed to help manage using different property sets for different environments. For example, it supports different runtime environments (production, development, others in between), specific properties for when running in an IDE, specific properties for different users as well as for different machines and operating systems.

This gives flexibility in the property sets that are loaded into the runtime, whether in development or deployment. It also allows changes to be made very cheaply, simply by changing system properties and restarting, rather than having to recompile code with new values for constants.

Priority Ordering of Property Sets

With highest priority property sets first. Properties specified in a higher priority property set will override those defined in lower priority property sets.

  1. System properties These override everything else.
  2. User properties taken from files defined by bootstrap.properties.user.file. These often define the environment for the running process, by setting the bootstrap.environment property.
  3. Machine properties taken from files defined by bootstrap.properties.machine.file.
  4. Operating-system properties taken from files defined by bootstrap.properties.os.file, defaulting to windows.properties and unix.properties. For example, set templated paths to common shared file locations, which will be used elsewhere. Consider my.path.to.stuff=C:/foo or my.path.to.stuff=/mnt/foo, for example.
  5. IDE properties taken from files defined by bootstrap.properties.ide.file. This might set properties to turn on debug modes, or turn off features like emails that should not be sent while debugging.
  6. Environment properties taken from files defined by bootstrap.properties.env.file. This defines the environment, for example the production/development database URLs, paths to environment-specific files etc.
  7. Common properties taken from files defined by bootstrap.properties.common.file. Define here those properties that are common to all environments, or sensible defaults.
Note that between all property sets, properties are resolved where values contain keys to other properties. The syntax for this looks like the following. 
 some.property=some.value
 my.template.property=abc.${some.property}
Here, the value my.template.property will be resolved to abc.some.value.

Note, also, that these two lines can be defined in different places. The property resolution step happens very late in order to catch this. As usual, higher priority properties take precedence when looking for the resolved values. Nested properties are supported in the usual manner.

Usage

There are two usage patterns.

  • Calling into BootstrapMain to configure properties

    Call prepareProperties() from your main method. This will configure all properties in the environment, if bootstrapping is enabled by such a property. Note that since properties will not be configured before this method is invoked, they will not be visible from static initialisers of the main class.

  • BootstrapMain as a main class

    Specify the application entry point class using the bootstrap.main.class property and the main method name using the bootstrap.main.method property. These must be defined somewhere within the property hierarchy.

    The application main thread will run within the scope of bootstrapper stack frames, and the main class will be this class. Note that tools such as jps will report on this main class name, which may make it more difficult to disambiguate running bootstrapped processes.

Summary of Understood Properties

PropertyBehaviourDefault value
bootstrap.enabletrue to enable bootstrapping behaviour. No changes will be made to the application environment without this property set. false
bootstrap.logging.enableTurns on verbose logging of properties found and set.false
bootstrap.logging.julLogs through java.util.logging instead of System.out.false (uses System.out)
bootstrap.environmentSpecifies the name of the environment.(none)
bootstrap.application.nameSpecifies the name of the application.(none)
bootstrap.main.classSpecifies the name of the entry point class for the application. This is used only by the launchApplication() family of methods. If not set, then the bootstrapper will attempt to set this property to the detected main class, by scanning the stack trace of the bootstrapping thread.(none)
bootstrap.main.methodSpecifies the name of the entry point method for the application. This is used only by the launchApplication() family of methods.(none)
bootstrap.properties.root.dirRoot directory in which to look for properties files. This may only be specified in system properties.config
bootstrap.properties.user.fileComma separated list of file names, relative to the root directory specified by bootstrap.properties.root.dir, in which to look for user properties files.<user_name>.properties, user.properties
bootstrap.properties.machine.fileFile name, relative to the root directory specified by bootstrap.properties.root.dir, in which to look for a machine-specific properties file. <hostname>.properties, determined by InetAddress.getLocalHost().getHostName()
bootstrap.properties.os.fileFile name, relative to the root directory specified by bootstrap.properties.root.dir, in which to look for a OS-specific properties file. windows.properties or unix.properties, determined by parsing the system property os.name. See SystemUtils.getOperatingSystem()
bootstrap.properties.ide.fileFile name, relative to the root directory specified by bootstrap.properties.root.dir, in which to look for an IDE properties file. Note that if this file is present, its properties will be loaded. So to prevent these properties from being loaded into your production runtime, either set bootstrap.properties.ide.file to empty or add a build step to remove this file from deployments.ide.properties
bootstrap.properties.env.fileFile name, relative to the root directory specified by bootstrap.properties.root.dir, in which to look for a environment-specific properties file. ${bootstrap.environment}.properties
bootstrap.properties.common.fileFile name, relative to the root directory specified by bootstrap.properties.root.dir, in which to look for a common properties file. common.properties

Author:
Joe Kearney

Method Detail

withCustomPropertySupplier

public static BootstrapMain.BootstrapBuilder withCustomPropertySupplier(PropertySupplier propertySupplier)
Specifies a custom property supplier for the application bootstrapper. Only use this if you want to override the default behaviour which reads from files determined by the current system property values. See the BootstrapMain class-level documentation for details of these.

Parameters:
propertySupplier - the property supplier
Returns:
the builder

Returns:

withApplicationName

public static BootstrapMain.BootstrapBuilder withApplicationName(java.lang.String appName)
Sets an application name for this process, which will be subsequently accessible through the BOOTSTRAP_APPLICATION_NAME_KEY system property. If a value is already set in any other property, this value will not override it.

Parameters:
appName - application name to set
Returns:
the builder
See Also:
BOOTSTRAP_APPLICATION_NAME_KEY

loadPropertiesForEnvironment

public static BootstrapResult loadPropertiesForEnvironment(java.lang.String bootstrapEnvironment)
Finds property sources for this application and builds the application's runtime property set, but does not publish the properties into the System properties map.

Returns:
an object providing access to the state of the properties before and after bootstrapping
See Also:
prepareProperties()

prepareProperties

public static BootstrapResult prepareProperties()
Finds property sources for this application, builds the application's runtime property set and publishes them to the System property map.

This does all of the work of the bootstrapper except for actually launching the application, for which you should consider using launchApplication(Class) or the builder API through withMainArgs(String...).

Returns:
an object providing access to the state of the properties before and after bootstrapping

launchApplication

public static void launchApplication(java.lang.Class<?> mainClass)
Launches the application with the given entry point and no main arguments.

Parameters:
mainClass - entry point to the application

launchApplication

public static void launchApplication()
Launches the application with entry point defined in properties and no main arguments.

Note: this launch method is applicable only when properties have been set to determine entry point method and class.

See Also:
BOOTSTRAP_MAIN_CLASS_KEY, BOOTSTRAP_MAIN_METHOD_KEY
